title: Is philosophy a part of STEM, and if not, what’s the difference? - Quora

response.answer_text: Darryn Reid has pointed out that modern science has roots in Philosophy. However, it is considered in many colleges to be a part of liberal arts. What can you do with a philosophy degree? | BestColleges.com Note this historical development: “The four medieval faculties of artes – variously called philosophy, letters, arts, arts and sciences, and humanities –, law, medicine, and theology have survived and have been supplemented by numerous disciplines, particularly the social sciences and technological studies, but they remain none the less at the heart of universities throughout the world.” taken from: List of early modern universities in Europe - Wikipedia And since Math is one of the foundations of STEM (they “M” part, LOL), you have this to ponder: BA and the BS Degrees Last, studies have shown that the IQ of philosophy rivals physics majors. Again, think about that for awhile.

Partly yes and partly no. Philosophy is woven throughout the mathematically oriented sciences; indeed, science was not a separate field from philosophy until the 19th century. Prior to this, early scientists described themselves as natural philosophers. Areas where philosophy heavily overlaps with mathematical sciences such as formal logic will still be considered part of STEM, as will a lot of very philosophically-oriented areas of mathematics, such as metamathematics. Other areas of philosophy such as epistemology and methodology should be more prominent in STEM than they are, but that doesn't mean it has to be part of STEM per se.
